title: Did Democrats get their smoking gun for impeachment?
text:
Did Democrats get their smoking gun for impeachment? Presented by Alibaba

with help from John Bresnahan

WHEN IT UKRAINES, IT POURS -- While you were sleeping, Democrats released a trove of explosive text messages between U.S. diplomats and a senior Ukrainian aide — and boy, they are a doozy. The text messages — which former special envoy to Ukraine Kurt Volker turned over to House investigators during his deposition yesterday — outline how senior State Department officials were deeply alarmed that the Trump administration would try to make foreign aid to Ukraine (as well as a White House visit) contingent on efforts to help the president’s reelection campaign. And they also demonstrate how U.S. diplomats were pushing Ukraine to probe Biden and the 2016 election on Trump's behalf.

Democrats will likely say they’ve got their smoking gun, and will certainly use the text messages as more ammo for impeachment. But Republicans, who insist that Volker testified that Trump never sought a “quid pro quo” from Ukraine, say the texts were cherry picked and are calling on Democrats to release a full transcript of Volker’s deposition . Here is a highlight of some of the texts:



“I think it’s crazy to withhold security assistance for help with a political campaign,” said Bill Taylor, the chargé d’affaires at the U.S. Embassy in Ukraine’s capital, Kiev, in a Sept. 9 text message. But Gordon Sondland, U.S. ambassador to the European Union, strongly denied to Taylor that this was Trump’s purpose. Two days later, the foreign aid was released.

Another text between Volker and Andrey Yermak, a top adviser to Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelensky, on July 25 — the day of the Trump-Zelenksy call — directly linked a Zelensky visit to Washington to whether the Ukrainians moved ahead with a probe into the 2016 election. Volker said: "Heard from the White House. Assuming President Z convinces [T]rump he will investigate/ 'get to the bottom of what happened in 2016, we will nail down date for visit to Washington."

"I think potus really wants the deliverable," Gordon texted Volker on August 9, when discussing potential meeting dates. Yermak responded with a reference to “Bursima”, the gas company where Joe Biden’s son was a board member. "Once we have a date, will call for a press briefing, announcing upcoming visit and outlining vision for the US-UKRAINE relationship, including among other things Burisma and election meddling in investigations," Yermak texted back.

"Are we now saying that security assistance and WH meeting are conditioned on investigations?" Taylor texted Sondland on September 1. Sondland's response: "Call me,” he texted.

BUT, WAIT THERE’S MORE ... The text messages weren’t the only bombshell stories that dropped last night. Here is a roundup of some of the other important news reports that you don’t want to miss:

— "Trump Ordered Ukraine Ambassador Removed After Complaints From Giuliani, Others," by WSJ’s Rebecca Ballhaus, Mike Bender and Vivian Salama: https://on.wsj.com/30KFvL1 .

— "Trump Envoys Pushed Ukraine to Commit to Investigations," per Ken Vogel and Mike Schmidt of the NYT: https://nyti.ms/359jR6z .

—"Trump raised Biden with Xi in June call housed in highly secure server," via Kylie Atwood, Kevin Liptak, Pamela Brown, Jim Sciutto and Gloria Borger: https://cnn.it/2VdNIX5 .

— “IRS whistleblower said to report Treasury political appointee might have tried to interfere in audit of Trump or Pence,” from WaPo’s Jeff Stein, Tom Hamburger and Josh Dawsey: https://wapo.st/331SjhK .

WASHINGTON, DC - OCTOBER 03: Former Special Envoy to Ukraine Kurt Volker departs following a closed-door deposition led by the House Intelligence Committee on Capitol Hill on October 3, 2019 in Washington, DC. Volker resigned from his position on September 27. (Photo by Zach Gibson/Getty Images) | Zach Gibson/Getty Images

A SCHIFF-TING STRATEGY -- When they get back from recess, House Republicans are planning to force a floor vote on a censure resolution condemning Adam Schiff, scoop your Huddle host and Burgess. The symbolic move represents the GOP’s latest offensive in the intensifying impeachment battle as the party struggles to defend Trump. And without a clear strategy from the White House, the GOP has been taking their cues from the president, who has been treating House Intelligence Chairman Schiff as a punching bag in the impeachment fight.

The eagerness to demonize Schiff demonstrates Republicans’ deep reluctance to opine on whether it was appropriate for Trump to ask Ukraine to dig up dirt on a political opponent. But that conversation is getting more difficult to avoid, especially after Trump on Thursday called for China to open up an investigation into the Biden family — which is at the center of Democrats’ impeachment investigation. And most Hill Republicans kept quiet. The dispatch: https://politi.co/2IkTYaa .

Meanwhile, the latest White House strategy is to essentially dare Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) to hold a floor vote on impeachment. According to Axios, the White House will send a letter to Pelosi later today arguing that the administration can ignore lawmakers' demands until she holds a full House vote to formally approve an inquiry. A senior Democratic aide shot back: “Given that the President just … urged yet another foreign government to meddle in our upcoming 2020 elections, we would think the White House would want to mount a rigorous defense of the President’s clear betrayal of his oath of office.” The story from Alayna Treene and Margaret Talev: http://bit.ly/2OlmzzY .

Related reads: “Republicans Call For A Kavanaugh-Like Strategy In Whistleblower Fight,” via NPR’s Franco Ordoñez: https://n.pr/2odpqAo ; and “'Americans don’t look to Chinese commies for the truth': Sasse decries Trump's call for probe,” by Joseph Morton of the Omaha World-Herald: http://bit.ly/2OkNmfY .

HAPPY FRIDAY! Welcome to Huddle, the play-by-play guide to all things Capitol Hill, on this October 4, where your host didn't think Nickelback could be any more hated.

THURSDAY’S MOST CLICKED: Roll Call’s report on Democrats being divided over how much evidence they need to impeach Trump.

A message from Alibaba: Alibaba’s strategy in the U.S. is simple: enabling American businesses to tap into the massive and rising consumer demand in China and other emerging economies. To learn about how Alibaba works with American brands, farmers, small businesses and tourist destinations, visit www.politico.com/sponsor-content/alibaba

FIRST IN HUDDLE -- Remember when Democrats on the House Oversight Committee promised to give notice to Republicans and allow a debate whenever they planned to issue a subpoena to the White House? Well, the GOP sure does – and they say Chairman Elijah Cummings (D-Md.) is breaking that pledge. Rep. Jim Jordan of Ohio, the top Republican on the committee, is sending a letter to Cummings this morning objecting to their latest subpoena threat and warning that if they follow through, it would “trample on long-held minority rights in the House of Representatives.”

“Most troubling, your actions are in violation of the letter and spirit of our bipartisan agreement about subpoenas,” Jordan writes in the letter. “You have failed to articulate a legitimate reason why you are violating our bipartisan agreement.” In recent days, Republicans have really zeroed in on process concerns, saying the entire impeachment inquiry has been unfair and violated norms. (House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) also fired off a letter to Pelosi yesterday demanding that she halt the inquiry until Democrats answer more questions about the process.) The letter from Jordan: https://politi.co/2AGlcE1.

Pic of the day… Per Bloomberg’s Steve Dennis: “Schiff condemns Trump as Mark Meadows looks on.” The scene.

Related: “McConnell signaling Trump trial to be quick, if it happens,” by The Hill’s Alexander Bolton: http://bit.ly/358WJVJ .

RECESS ON THE ROAD -- Several moderate Democrats who represent Trump-won districts have faced little impeachment backlash so far, reports The Los Angeles Times, as lawmakers head back home for the first time since the House launched a formal inquiry. The dispatch from Jennifer Haberkorn: “At three town hall meetings in Pennsylvania and New York districts that voted for Trump in 2016, backlash to the Democrats’ impeachment inquiry was rare and only from loyal Trump supporters — not the key independent and moderate voters that Democrats will need for victory in 2020 in Congress and the White House.”

“In interviews with voters at the events, self-identified Democrats said they were pleased, albeit some only cautiously, that the House decided to formally launch the inquiry. And in many cases, voters were more concerned about other issues, such as healthcare, climate policy and local transit service,” Haberkorn writes. “Moderate Democratic lawmakers in these places will have to find a way to keep the support of progressive Democrats — many of whom have long wanted an impeachment inquiry — and not lose the votes of moderates and independents, who either support Trump or are skeptical that impeachment is warranted.” The story: https://lat.ms/331JBjt .

BROS BEFORE JOES -- As you’ll recall, Sen. Ed Markey (D-Mass.) picked up a high-profile endorsement from liberal superstar Rep. Alexandria Ocasio Cortez in his primary race against Rep. Joe Kennedy (D-Mass.). But it looks like Kennedy has someone else in his corner who is familiar with primary battles: former Rep. Joe Crowley, the New York Democrat who was toppled by AOC in a primary battle last year. The Boston Globe reports that Crowley is listed as one of the hosts for an Oct. 15 fundraiser for Kennedy’s Senate campaign. Much more from Victoria McGrane: http://bit.ly/2VdNIWQ .

Related: “Joe Lieberman's son running for Senate in Georgia,” via James Arkin: https://politi.co/2OfAAiN .

WEEKLY WINNERS AND LOSERS -- We are almost near the end of week two of impeachment, and there was no shortage of news cycle to keep our heads spinning. So, who took the W and who took the L? Here are our picks:

W: Democratic oversight efforts. After months of being successfully stonewalled by the Trump administration, Democrats are finally breaking through when it comes to Ukraine. They got key testimony from Volker, a trove of revealing text messages and a package of conspiracy theories that Rudy Giuliani sent to the administration — all of which they will undoubtedly use to build their impeachment case.

L: GOP messaging. While congressional leaders are now trying to right the ship, Republicans have grown increasingly anxious this week that the White House doesn’t have a clear, centralized strategy to deal with impeachment. And some Republicans have been uncomfortable with several of the attacks that Trump has launched.





TRANSITIONS

Jesse Lee is returning to Speaker Nancy Pelosi's (D-Calif.) office as senior adviser in her communications operation. Lee, who served as Pelosi's new media adviser during her first speakership, most recently worked at the Center for American Progress. The hire comes as Pelosi's communications team recalibrates to deal with the impeachment inquiry and need for increased message coordination.

TODAY IN CONGRESS

The House and Senate are out.

AROUND THE HILL

All is quiet… for now.

TRIVIA

THURSDAY’S WINNER: Bob Bissen was the first person to correctly guess that there have been eight left-handed presidents, with Obama being the most recent one.

TODAY’S QUESTION: From Bob: Given that there were 13 states at time, there were 26 Senators when the First Congress convened in 1789. But how many members were there in the House of Representatives and how were they aligned? First person to correctly guess gets a mention in the next edition of Huddle. Send your best guess my way: mzanona@politico.com

GET HUDDLE emailed to your phone each morning.
